newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU to launch debate on food laws.
newsitem.headline: EU to launch debate on food laws.

text.p: The European Commission is set to launch a debate on Wednesday on how to ensure that European Union food laws both protect consumers and promote cross-border trade.

The European Union executive is expected to adopt a "green paper", or discussion document, on food policy that places a heavy emphasis on public health, reflecting its sensitivity to criticism that the EU mishandled the mad cow disease crisis.

While the paper was promised several years ago as an initiative to streamline EU food regulations, it now says that "simplification cannot be allowed to result in a reduction in the level of protection of public health or consumer protection," according to a summary obtained by Reuters.

When foods pose a health danger, the EU should take protective measures based on scientific evidence, inspections and testing, it says, adding, "the importance of an independent source of advice which will command public respect is crucial".
The Commission asks for comments on possible changes to EU procedures for controlling "zoonoses" -- diseases that can be passed from animals to humans.
That could involve making all those involved in food production liable for ensuring that all food placed on the market is safe, it said.

On labelling -- one of the biggest controversies surrounding the introduction of genetically modified foods in the EU -- the paper calls for an approach that ensures that consumers receive all useful information but not unnecessary details.
It notes that EU laws do not require production methods to be labelled unless they change the characteristics of the finished product -- which does not always apply to genetically modified foods.
But it says consumer interest in the question could warrant setting up an EU framework for voluntary labelling schemes.
Despite concern over consumer safety, the Commission argues that a simplified approach to food laws can be justified in some cases.
It says simplified procedures would make it easier to adapt EU rules to new scientific findings and notes that it has already started work on streamlining EU food hygiene regulations.
The paper was delayed until now partly because of an internal argument in the Commission over whether it should cover agricultural products or only processed foods.

The text now insists that the regulatory approach should cover the whole food chain "from the stable to the table", but asks whether the two categories of goods should be covered by the same set of rules.
